timeline.body:
what about a more functional style, suggestion:
```
transformer.transform(transformation.getCompiledExpression(),
                              Optional.ofNullable(event)
                                      .filter(Map.class::isInstance)
                                      .map(Map.class::cast)
                                      .orElseGet(() -> Collections.singletonMap(name, event)));
```
timeline.bodyText:
what about a more functional style, suggestion:
transformer.transform(transformation.getCompiledExpression(),
                              Optional.ofNullable(event)
                                      .filter(Map.class::isInstance)
                                      .map(Map.class::cast)
                                      .orElseGet(() -> Collections.singletonMap(name, event)));
timeline.bodyHTML:
what about a more functional style, suggestion:

transformer.transform(transformation.getCompiledExpression(),
                              Optional.ofNullable(event)
                                      .filter(Map.class::isInstance)
                                      .map(Map.class::cast)
                                      .orElseGet(() -> Collections.singletonMap(name, event)));
timeline.author: tiagodolphine

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
doAnswer(new Answer<AsyncResult<HttpResponse<Buffer>>>() {
@Override
public AsyncResult<HttpResponse<Buffer>> answer(InvocationOnMock arg0) throws Throwable {
((Handler<AsyncResult<HttpResponse<Buffer>>>) arg0.getArgument(0)).handle(asyncResult);
return null;
}
}).when(request).send(any());
doAnswer(invocationOnMock -> {
Handler<AsyncResult<HttpResponse<Buffer>>> handler = invocationOnMock.getArgument(0);
handler.handle(asyncResult);
return null;
}).when(request).send(any());

What about this? Looks much cleaner and gets rid of some unchecked warnings.
timeline.author: MarianMacik

replies.bodyText: I checked the code and there seems to be no blocking method when calling promise.future() or future.result(). According to IDE Promise.promise() returns just FutureImpl and its result() method is basically just a getter. I understand that the only thing what Promise does is to be able to set Handler which is called after the work is done. Here we could set a handler on the future but we need to wait there for the time to be returned. So perhaps we need vertx-sync method? Maybe I am wrong, not sure.
replies.author: MarianMacik

replies.bodyText: replaced with java CompletableFuture instead and updated test to make sure this works now. thanks
replies.author: mswiderski

timeline.body:
How was this handled before?

I see that before there was just a consequence (string) set. And that consequence was then code-generated as a lambda to `action()` builder method in the `ActionNodeVisitor` (`actionNode.getAction().toString()` actually returns consequence):

https://github.com/kiegroup/kogito-runtimes/blob/fba1a5e7a7b87c154cc364cb0c1b08cae11621f8/jbpm/jbpm-flow-builder/src/main/java/org/jbpm/compiler/canonical/ActionNodeVisitor.java#L95-L97

So right now the consequence is an empty string, so the compilation is no-op. But how is this then translated to the generated `ActionNode` in case of a throw signal node? The action has to be somehow registered on the generated node as well, right?
timeline.bodyText:
How was this handled before?
I see that before there was just a consequence (string) set. And that consequence was then code-generated as a lambda to action() builder method in the ActionNodeVisitor (actionNode.getAction().toString() actually returns consequence):

  
    
      kogito-runtimes/jbpm/jbpm-flow-builder/src/main/java/org/jbpm/compiler/canonical/ActionNodeVisitor.java
    
    
        Lines 95 to 97
      in
      fba1a5e
    
    
    
    

        
          
           actionBody.addStatement(new NameExpr(actionNode.getAction().toString())); 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
           body.addStatement(getFactoryMethod(getNodeId(node), METHOD_ACTION, lambda)); 
        
    
  


So right now the consequence is an empty string, so the compilation is no-op. But how is this then translated to the generated ActionNode in case of a throw signal node? The action has to be somehow registered on the generated node as well, right?
timeline.bodyHTML:
How was this handled before?

I see that before there was just a consequence (string) set. And that consequence was then code-generated as a lambda to action() builder method in the ActionNodeVisitor (actionNode.getAction().toString() actually returns consequence):

kogito-runtimes/jbpm/jbpm-flow-builder/src/main/java/org/jbpm/compiler/canonical/ActionNodeVisitor.java

Lines 95 to 97 in fba1a5e

actionBody.addStatement(new NameExpr(actionNode.getAction().toString()));
body.addStatement(getFactoryMethod(getNodeId(node), METHOD_ACTION, lambda));

So right now the consequence is an empty string, so the compilation is no-op. But how is this then translated to the generated ActionNode in case of a throw signal node? The action has to be somehow registered on the generated node as well, right?
timeline.author: MarianMacik

replies.bodyText: there is no need to do any compilation as the action is already given as actual java class. It was not handled before at all, as this was never implemented for code gen. ActionNodes that represent Script Tasks were implemented but not the internal use of ActionNodes like this.
replies.author: mswiderski

replies.bodyText: So now it is implemented for codegen? Because that's what I am asking. In that ActionNodeVisitor the lambda will be now empty I guess as we no longer specify a String action but a Java class, so how is the action generated now?
replies.author: MarianMacik

replies.bodyText: if this is implemented in code get it's more of a question if fluent api supports it. Once fluent api will support it will work fine. So it's prerequisite to make use of this constructs. Note that the changes where done on parser side so similar would have to be done on fluent api.
replies.author: mswiderski

timeline.message: Remove getSignalExpression method as it is unused

KOGITO-2040 - Implemented getScheduledTime for JobsService to align it with actual capability of the jobs-service module, KOGITO-2041 - Expose process name via Process interface to be able to provide more human readable version of the process
KOGITO-2042 - Pass variable definitions via BpmnProcess and BpmnVariables, allow to filter variables on BpmnVariables
KOGITO-2043 - Externalize process instance description via function interface so different expression evaluators can be used
KOGITO-2044 - Replace string based signal expressions with java classes to avoid need for compilation
Remove getSignalExpression method as it is unused
Remove getSignalExpression method as it is unused
